Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: The Next Generation of the Penn World Table

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the Penn World Table (PWT). This is a data resource for making international comparisons of economic performance (income, output, and production) across countries. The data have been widely used both as a dependent variable to be explained (studies of the determinants of economic performance) and as a control variable included in other studies as a way to control for differences across countries in economic resources.

The PWT continues to be updated on a regular basis to take into account changes in economic performance. In addition to requesting support for these updates, the PIs want to improve the methods used to make the international comparisons. The PWT has relied in part on a comparison program conducted by the UN and the World Bank. That comparison has focused on the expenditure side of national accounts (what a country consumes, invests, spends on government activities, exports, and imports). An alternative way to compare economies is to consider the production side of national accounts. The PWT team is collaborating with a leading European research group to incorporate these production comparisons into the PWT. They develop separate estimates of production and income that are comparable across countries, and use several different analytic approaches in order to appraise which approach is most effective for future maintenance of the PWT.

They also develop improved models of the relationship between implicit growth rates implied by their comparisons to national growth rates calculated through national income accounts. The question is how to use economic theory and empirical methods to best account for economic growth when both economic structures and relative prices are changing over time.

The Penn World Tables are widely used by researchers, policymakers, and students who are interested in international economic comparisons.

Institution.Name: National Bureau of Economic Research Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: NATIONAL BUREAU OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: National Bureau of Economic Research Inc

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work focused on preparing a new generation of a major international economic database used in economic and social science research: the Penn World Table (PWT). The work both updated this database and broadened it to incorporate new measures of international economic performance.

We developed two main sets of economic theory to achieve this:

  • theory needed to construct quality-adjusted prices in international trade that was implementable over a very large database of close to 1,000 products for nearly 200 countries, from 1984-2011. We henceforth refer to the resulting data as the “UC Davis data”.
  • theory needed to combine International Comparison Project (ICP) data on prices of consumption, investment and government expenditures with the UC Davis data on quality-adjusted prices in trade, implementable for all countries included in the 2005 and the 2011 ICP.  This objective also requires merging the ICP and UC Davis data with the national accounts data from all countries, since the national accounts data is used for interpolation and extrapolation of results from ICP rounds.

After developing this theory we were able to compute real GDP for all ICP countries on the expenditure side and on the production side. Previously, the PWT only computed real GDP on the expenditure side, i.e. it was a measure of the standard of living of countries, but not a measure of their production capabilities. With new estimates of real GDP on the production side, we also have a measure of their productive capabilities. The difference between these two measures of real GDP arise from the opportunity to engage in international trade. The two measures are useful for different types of economic and broader social science research: researchers interested in comparisons of the standard of living concepts will use the expenditure-based measure, while researchers interested in studying productivity concepts will use the production-based measure. Our results are widely disseminated through progressive updates of the PWT. The latest version of the PWT, PWT 9.0 (released on June 9, 2016) and is available at http://www.rug.nl/research/ggdc/data/pwt/pwt-9.0., which have been visited on hundreds of thousands of occasions.

The project produced significant scholarly publications published in leading economics journals that have been cited 1645 times:

  • “Who Shrunk China? Puzzles in the Measurement of Real GDP,” by Robert C. Feenstra, Hong Ma, J. Peter Neary, and D.S. Prasada Rao was published in The Economic Journal (Volume 123, Issue 573), 2013.  
  • "International Prices and Endogenous Quality," by Robert C. Feenstra and John Romalis was published in The Quarterly Journal of Economics (Volume 129, Issue 2), 2014.
  • “The Relative Price of Services” by Robert Inklaar and Marcel Timmer was published in The Review of Income and Wealth (Volume 60, Issue 4), 2014.
  • "The Next Generation of the Penn World Table," by Robert C. Feenstra, Robert Inklaar and Marcel Timmer was published in the American Economic Review (Volume 105, Issue 10), 2015.
  • “Measuring industry productivity and cross-country convergence” by Robert Inklaar and W. Erwin Diewert was published in the Journal of Econometrics (Volume 191, Issue 2), 2016.
  • “Cross-country income levels over time: did the developing world suddenly become much richer?”, by Robert Inklaar, University of Groningen, and D.S. Prasada Rao, University of Queensland, was published in the American Economic Journal: Macroeconomics (Volume 9, Issue 1), 2017.

The project produced four current working papers that have been cited 42 times:

  • “What is the Price of Tea in China?: Towards a Comparison of the Relative Cost of Living in Chinese and U.S. Cities”, by Robert Feenstra, UC Davis, Alexis Antoniades, Georgetown University, and Mingzhi Xu, UC Davis.
  • “Tariff Reductions, Entry, and Welfare: Theory and Evidence for the Last Two Decades,” Robert C. Feenstra, Lorenzo Caliendo, John Romalis and Alan M. Taylor, NBER Working Paper No. 21768, 2016.
  • “Statistics to Measure Offshoring and its Impact,” NBER Working Paper No. 23067, 2017.
  • “How Did China’s WTO Entry Benefit U.S. Consumers?” NBER Working Paper No. 23487, 2017, with Mary Amiti, Mi Dai, and John Romalis.

The project supported several academic conferences:

  • 2012 Penn World Tables Workshop, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, May 17-18, organized by Alan Heston and Robert Feenstra.
  • Princeton Conference on ICP/PPP, Princeton University, Princeton NJ, May 23-24, 2013, organized by Orley Ashenfelter, Angus Deaton, and Robert Feenstra.
  • International Comparison of Income, Prices and Production, May 15-16, 2014, UC Davis, organized by Robert Feenstra.
  • International Comparison of Income, Prices and Production, May 22-23, 2015, CERGE-EI, Prague, co-organized by Robert Feenstra.
  • International Comparisons of Income, Prices and Production, MIT Sloan, Cambridge MA, May 27-28, 2016, organized by Robert Feenstra and Alberto Cavallo.
  • International Comparisons of Income, Prices and Production, May 25-26, 2017, Princeton University, Princeton NJ, Organized by Orley Ashenfelter, Angus Deaton, and Robert Feenstra.

Project research was presented in dozens of academic seminars and conferences. Finally, the project supported training of graduate and undergraduate research assistants.


Last Modified: 10/23/2017
Modified by: John Romalis
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Our work focused on preparing a new generation of a major international economic database used in economic and social science research: the Penn World Table (PWT). The work both updated this database and broadened it to incorporate new measures of international economic performance. We developed two main sets of economic theory to achieve this: theory needed to construct quality-adjusted prices in international trade that was implementable over a very large database of close to 1,000 products for nearly 200 countries, from 1984-2011. We henceforth refer to the resulting data as the "UC Davis data". theory needed to combine International Comparison Project (ICP) data on prices of consumption, investment and government expenditures with the UC Davis data on quality-adjusted prices in trade, implementable for all countries included in the 2005 and the 2011 ICP. This objective also requires merging the ICP and UC Davis data with the national accounts data from all countries, since the national accounts data is used for interpolation and extrapolation of results from ICP rounds. After developing this theory we were able to compute real GDP for all ICP countries on the expenditure side and on the production side. Previously, the PWT only computed real GDP on the expenditure side, i.e. it was a measure of the standard of living of countries, but not a measure of their production capabilities. With new estimates of real GDP on the production side, we also have a measure of their productive capabilities. The difference between these two measures of real GDP arise from the opportunity to engage in international trade. The two measures are useful for different types of economic and broader social science research: researchers interested in comparisons of the standard of living concepts will use the expenditure-based measure, while researchers interested in studying productivity concepts will use the production-based measure. Our results are widely disseminated through progressive updates of the PWT. The project produced four current working papers that have been cited 42 times: "What is the Price of Tea in China?: Towards a Comparison of the Relative Cost of Living in Chinese and U.S. Cities", by Robert Feenstra, UC Davis, Alexis Antoniades, Georgetown University, and Mingzhi Xu, UC Davis. "Tariff Reductions, Entry, and Welfare: Theory and Evidence for the Last Two Decades," Robert C. Feenstra, Lorenzo Caliendo, John Romalis and Alan M. Taylor, NBER Working Paper No. 21768, 2016. NBER Working Paper No. 23487, 2017, with Mary Amiti, Mi Dai, and John Romalis.
